ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

Global validity. Rate
Notes: 0=Excellent, no reason to suspect invalid responses; 1=Good, factors present that may adversely affect validity; 2=Fair, factors present that definitely reduce validity; 3=Poor, substantially reduced validity; 4=Invalid responses, severely impaired mental status or possible deliberate "faking bad" or "faking good"

ElementDescription: Global severity. Rate
Notes: 0= No clinically significant symptoms, no distress and no functional impairment; 1=Mild, minimal distress or functional impairment; 2= Moderate, definite distress or functional impairment but functions satisfactorily with effort; 3=Severe, considerable distress or functional impairment, limited functioning even with effort; 4= Extreme, marked distress or marked impairment in two or more major areas of functioning

ElementDescription: Global improvement. Rate
Notes: 0= Asymptomatic; 1=Considerable improvement; 2=Moderate improvement; 3=Slight improvement; 4=No improvement; 5=Insufficient information;7 = N/A

ElementDescription: Depersonalization: Persistent or recurrent experiences of feeling detached from, and as if one were anoutside observer of, one�s mental processes or body (e.g., feeling as though one were in a dream; feeling a sense ofunreality of self or body or of time moving slowly).

ElementDescription: Past month: Have these PTSD symptoms affected your relationships with other people/social life?
Notes: 0 = No adverse impact; 1 = Mild impact (minimal impairment in social functioning); 2 = Moderate impact (definite impairment, but many aspects of social functioning still intact); 3 = Severe impact (marked impairment, few aspects of social functioning still intact); 4 = Extreme impact (little or no social functioning)

Notes: 0 = No adverse impact; 1 = Mild impact (minimal impairment in social functioning); 2 = Moderate impact (definite impairment, but many aspects of social functioning still intact); 3 = Severe impact (marked impairment, few aspects of social functioning still intact); 4 = Extreme impact (little or no social functioning)

Notes: 0 = No adverse impact; 1 = Mild impact (minimal impairment in occupational/other important functioning); 2 = Moderate impact (definite impairment, but many aspects of occupational/other important functioning still intact); 3 = Severe impact (marked impairment, few aspects of occupational/other important functioning still intact); 4 = Extreme impact (little or no occupational/other important functioning)

ElementDescription: Past week: If working: Have these PTSD symptoms affected your work or your ability to work?
Notes: 0 = No adverse impact; 1 = Mild impact (minimal impairment in occupational/other important functioning); 2 = Moderate impact (definite impairment, but many aspects of occupational/other important functioning still intact); 3 = Severe impact (marked impairment, few aspects of occupational/other important functioning still intact); 4 = Extreme impact (little or no occupational/other important functioning)

ElementDescription: Having strong negative beliefs about yourself, other people, or the world (for example, having thoughts such as: I am bad, there is something seriously wrong with me, no one can be trusted, the word is completely dangerous)?
Notes: 1=not at all; 2= a little bit; 3=moderately; 4=quite a bit; 5= extremely; 999=NA/NK/missing/Refused

ElementDescription: Past month: Global Severity (degree of subjective distress and functional impairment, behavioral observations, judgment of reporting style)
Notes: 0 = No clinically significant symptoms (no distress and no functional impairment); 1 = Mild (minimal distress or functional impairment); 2 = Moderate (definite distress or functional impairment but functions satisfactorily with effort); 3 = Severe (considerable distress or functional impairment, limited functioning even with effort); 4 = Extreme (marked distress or marked impairment in two or more major areas of functioning)

ElementDescription: Past week: Global Severity (degree of subjective distress and functional impairment, behavioral observations, judgment of reporting style)

ElementDescription: Sometimes events that are unusual or especially frightening, horrible, or traumatic can happen to people - some examples being a serious accident, an earthquake, seeing someone who has been hurt, or being exposed to violence. Have you ever experienced this type of situation?
When answering these items, which type of events were you considering? (Mark all that apply) Natural Disaster (for example a flood, hurricane, tornado, earthquake, fire)
When answering these items, which type of events were you considering? (Mark all that apply) Transportation accident (for example a car accident, train wreck, plane crash)
When answering these items, which type of events were you considering? (Mark all that apply) Physical assault (for example being attacked, threatened with a weapon, beaten up)
When answering these items, which type of events were you considering? (Mark all that apply) Sexual assault (for example rape, attempted rape, unwanted sexual contact)
When answering these items, which type of events were you considering? (Mark all that apply) Emotional or verbal abuse (for example, people in my family repeatedly insulted me)
